awd_titl_txt: Explorations in High Energy Physics at the Large Hadron Collider with the ATLAS Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is devoted to research using ATLAS, a multi-purpose particle physics detector situated around the 27 km ring of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) located at CERN, the European particle physics laboratory near Geneva, Switzerland. The goal of the project is to explore the fundamental nature of the universe in order to understand its evolution from the hot, dense soup of energy and matter existing soon after the Big Bang to the cool, diffuse universe we see today.  The interactions and evolution of the fundamental constituents of the universe are well described by the Standard Model (SM) of Particle Physics that has been very successful in predicting the behavior of nature in the currently available energy regimes.  The LHC is expected to restart operations in 2015 after a two-year upgrade program that allows the proton-proton collisions to reach an energy of 13 Tera-electron-Volt, almost twice the highest energy yet produced in any human-made device.  This energy regime will allow for further understanding of the SM, exploration of the properties of the newly discovered Higgs Boson and the search for undiscovered particles and phenomena not described by the SM, yet believed to exist. 

In this research project Professor Moss and his group at California State University, Sacramento (Sacramento State) will probe the electroweak sector of the SM using data collected ATLAS to test the SM at the new energy regime and to search for new phenomena.  They propose to study couplings of Higgs Bosons to the electro-weak Z Bosons.  Moss and his group, along with their colleagues in ATLAS will perform studies to optimize the performance of the ATLAS Pixel Detector and Diamond Beam Monitor and develop software and user interfaces for the supervisory controls and data acquisition of the ATLAS Detector.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the ATLAS Experiment is to explore the fundamental nature of the universe in order to understand its evolution from the hot, dense soup of energy and matter that existed a few seconds after the Big Bang to the cool, diffuse world we see today. The theory that gives a description of the interaction and evolution of the fundamental constituents of the universe is called the Standard Model of Particle Physics and it has been very successful in predicting the behavior of nature in the currently available energy regimes. The LHC restarted operations in 2015 after a two-year upgrade program that allowed for proton-proton collisions at a center-of-mass energy of 13 TeV, which was the highest energy proton collisions yet produced. This new energy regime allowed  for further understanding of the Standard Model, exploration of the properties of the newly discovered Higgs Boson at a mass of approximately 125 GeV, and the continued search for undiscovered particles and phenomena such as heavy bosons, gravitons and leptoquarks. This award has supported the research of the California State University, Sacramento (Sacramento State) ATLAS Group  in its work where it has contributed to the study of the Standard Model in Data Analysis by probing the electroweak and Higgs sectors in ZZ production and HH production, operationally by contributing to studies of the performance of the ATLAS Pixel Detector and Inner Detector Tracking software (ART), and technically through contributions to the planning and building of the ATLAS Inner Tracker upgrade, the Fast Tracker Trigger, and the Diamond Beam Monitor. 

The ATLAS paper title "The Measurement of the ZZ Production Cross-Section and Limits on Anomalous Triple Gauge Couplings at a Center-of-Mass Energy of 8 TeV using the Four-Lepton Decay Channel" was published in the Journal of High Energy Physics (JHEP) in January 2017.   Studying proton-proton collision events which produced two Z boson allowed for a clean and precise test of the Standard Model's prediction.  Deviations from those predictions would be a sign of new physics that is not accounted for in the current model and could indicate particles and interactions that have not yet been measured or observed.  Using Monte Carlo statistical software, robust search algorithms, and precision understanding of the ATLAS detector, the Sacramento State ALTAS group provided the signal and background predictions and contributed to the statistical limits set on the strength of possible contributions from new physics 

Support from this award has allowed for significant contributions to the efforts to maintain and upgrade the ATLAS Detector.  At the end of 2025, operations at the LHC are expected to stop so that repairs and upgrades to the accelerator and the ATLAS Detector can be made in preparation for collisions provided by the High Luminosity LHC (HL- LHC).  To cope with the significant increase in tracks produced in each collision, a new Inner Tracker (ITk) will be installed in ATLAS and is expected to be operational for more than 10 years. The PI and the California State University ATLAS group have contributed to the design and prototyping of the Inner Pixel tracker which consists of the barrel and rings of pixel modules that are closest to the collision point.  Additionally, the group contributes to the safety systems and the Detector Control Systems (DCS) for the ITk.   The DCS monitors and controls the detector components and ensures safe operation through software controls and monitoring. Additionally, hardware interlocks are implemented that monitor the temperature, humidity and cooling systems inside the prototype's testing environment and switch off the prototype and cooling when unsafe conditions are present.  The first prototypes and testing environment have been built and installed for demonstrator systems.  The DCS's specifications have been determined and the first version of the software was designed and coded in WinCC (the CERN-supported Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) software) to display information to the prototype's users. 

Undergraduate students from Sacramento State have participated in ATLAS research for the duration of this award through the summer research program. Fourteen undergraduate students have been selected and trained to work on ATLAS projects for 10 weeks during the summer. Since 2016, eleven of those students have traveled to CERN to work alongside mentors from both US and international institutes on projects where they could make a substantive contribution while gaining vital research experience.   Students learn to program in C++, Python, Java, and ROOT while working in a collaborative environment and learn core skills for working with and building hardware such as electronic readout boards and pixel detectors.  Sacramento State is a Hispanic-serving and Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-serving institution and has a population which is 57% women, 41% underrepresented minority, and 30% first-generation college students.  This project created opportunities for a diverse and underrepresented population while helping young scientists gain significant STEM research experience.
